results.title: Sammy and Rosie get laid
results.creator_credit: Stephen Frears, Sarah Radclyffe, Tim Bevan and Sammy and Rosie Ltd
results.brief_description: With relentless momentum director Stephen Frears unfolds the story of Sammy the hedonistic, thoroughly English, son of a prominent Pakistani politician, who abandoned the young man and his mother in London years before to seek wealth and power in his homeland. Sammy, who scrapes out a living as an accountant, lives in a dangerous and decaying black neighbourhood with his wife Rosie, a sexually adventurous “modern woman” supportive of fashionable radical issues. Theirs is an open marriage based on, as Rosie puts it, “freedom plus commitment”. Change enters their lives with the arrival of Rafi, Sammy’s long lost father who has been forced to flee his political enemies in Pakistan. Struggling to maintain his self-dignity and his sanity in the terrifying environment of the city he no longer knows, Rafi rapidly becomes disenchanted by Sammy and Rosie’s unanchored world and tolerance of sexual liberty, drugs and revolutionary violence. As the demons of his past return to haunt Rafi, escape is impossible; personal tragedy is inevitable.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Frears, Sarah Radclyffe, Tim Bevan and Sammy and Rosie Ltd

results.title: Same difference: all about twins
results.brief_description: Discusses Siamese twins, how different twins are formed and how, with some, the bond is so close that they can feel each other’s pain. A fascinating study that looks at different types of twins including dissimilar twins and those that prefer to live separate lives.

results.title: Samba to slow fox
results.brief_description: A highly entertaining documentary about Australian ballroom dancing, from the competition glamour to interviews with the people inside the dancing shoes. This will appeal even to those who don’t know the difference between a samba and a slow fox. Rated: G

results.title: Sam Weller and his father
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Charles Dickens”.
Shows Sam Weller and his father collaborating on a plan to get Mr Pickwick out of the debtor’s prions and finally managing to give the detestable Mr Stiggins, a lay preacher, a sharp lesson. From the series “Tales from Dickens.”

results.title: Sam Spiegel in a discussion with Ludovic Kennedy on the producer and the film
results.brief_description: Sam Spiegel discusses his work as a film producer. Scenes from “Lawrence of Arabia”, “On the Waterfront”, “The African Queen” and “The Bridge on the River Kwai” are shown.

results.title: Sam Smith: Genuine England
results.creator_credit: Shaw Ashton, Andrew Lee and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: An insight into the life and work of Sam Smith, doll-maker extraordinaire. He relates snippets from his life as he discusses the making of his unusual dolls.

results.title: Sam Maloof: woodworker
results.brief_description: Sam Maloof is a craftsman who designs and builds his own furniture. The film demonstrates the working situation, methods and materials used by him. He talks of his philosophy in working with wood and the satisfaction he finds in his work.
results.description: Sam Maloof is a craftsman who designs and builds his own furniture. The film demonstrates the working situation, methods and materials used by him. He talks of his philosophy in working with wood and the satisfaction he finds in his work.

results.title: Sam Fullbrook
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Sam Fullbrook enjoyed a high reputation in the Australian art world for his painting as a colourist and mastery of the science of light and colour in his painting. Well travelled throughout Australia ‘teaming up’ on jobs such as mustering, jackarooing, labouring and house painting in the 1920’s-1950’s Fullbrook talks of the influences to him as painter: the light in the landscape, the spiritually ‘aristocratic ‘ nature of Aboriginal culture and house painting as one of the disciplines that he modelled his painting on. This documentary conversation with Fullbrook was taped over 17-18th December in Oakey, Queensland, 1985 and offers an insight to an artist living in Australia during very different times than today. As much as a portrait of the artist, this documentary offers as a primary source insights into a way of life unique to Australians during the depression and the post-war era.
